properties.Name: Kearney Hall
properties.description: In 2008 Kearney Hall was remodeled to provide the Civil Engineering and Construction Engineering Management programs with state-of-the-art classrooms, offices, and a 120 seat auditorium. The project received a LEED Gold rating by the US Green Building Council.

properties.Name: Kelley Engineering
properties.description: A certified LEED Gold building with the following features: 16,500 gallon rainwater collection system, modular raised floor system that allows air to circulate eliminating the need for ceiling air ducts, systems designed to use ~50% less electricity and ~70% less water than required, and much more.

properties.Name: Student Experience Center
properties.description: Completed in 2015, the SEC is home to the Student Sustainability Initiative (SSI) and many other student based organizations and boasts a number of sustainable features.

properties.Name: Food Forest
properties.description: Located outside of Callahan Hall, the Food Forest is a small student-and-volunteer-run organic garden that provides teaching and volunteering opportunities, as well as supplying University Housing and Dining Services (UHDS) with some fresh, organic produce.

properties.Name: OSUsed Store
properties.description: The OSUsed store serves as a donation center for surplus and donated items, which are then donated again elsewhere or sold to the public during designated sales hours. Shopping Hours: Tues. 5:30-7:30 pm, Fri. 12-3 pm.

properties.Name: International Living and Learning Center
properties.description: The ILLC is the equivalent of LEED Gold ratged and is the home of many innovative and sustainable features, as well as housing for international students.

properties.Name: Oak Creek Center for Urban Horticulture
properties.description: The site, located along Oak Creek, is tucked into a corner of campus once used to teach beekeeping.

properties.Name: 35th Street Solar Array
properties.description: A 1.435 megawatt array is located adjacent to the Campus Way bike path just west of OSU's farm services buildings. Sheep still graze this pasture, which now serves double duty providing electricity and grass. This installation produces enough electricity to power 167 homes for a year or offset CO2 emissions from 136,206 gallons of gasoline per year. This array is one of five large ground-mounted solar electric (photovoltaic) arrays installed on OSU land.
